I was sitting at my computer, typing up my outline for my speech on BASE jumping that I'm giving on Tuesday and I glance over at my open closet door and something catches my eye. My violin case, sitting at the bottom of my closet, lonely, untouched in who knows how long. I've probably played a few times since I quit at the end of my freshman year of high school, that was 4 years ago. Four long years of me not touching what used to be my most prized possession. So I grab the case and my bag of sheet music, forgetting about my outline. As I open the case, I smile. Its still there, my violin, sitting peacefully in its home, waiting all these years for me to bring it back out, let it do what it was made to do, make music. I gently pluck each string once. I can tell they are all slightly out of tune, a bit flat, but how much, I'm not sure. Its been too long since I've tuned my violin simply by ear. I'm proud that my ears could still tell the flatness was there. I put my shoulder rest on the instrument, still remembering which way it goes and pick up my bow. After I tighten and rosin it, my hand becomes one with the bow, holding it exactly as I was taught to so long ago, my fingers relaxed and gently curled over the bow. I position my violin in its familar spot, resting on my shoulder, held by my left cheek. I'm slightly surprised to find that my tuner still works and discover that I was right, all my strings were a little flat. I play a simple scale and smile as the notes echo in my otherwise silent room. I shuffle through my music, finding old songs I loved. I play piece after piece. Each song flows back into me, my fingers know what to do from memory without me realizing it. Song after song, memory after memory, regret after regret. Why did I quit? I missed playing my violin, didn't realize it, but I did. Eventually my fingertips start to numb from soreness, my jawbone aches. My body isn't used to playing, its been too long. Finally, I decide my fingers can't take anymore. One mistake after another. I gently put my violin and bow back into their oh-so-familar case with a joy knowing that its not going to be another 4 years before I pick it up again. I refuse to let myself lose that part of my past, which I loved so much.

I'm sitting on an uncomfortable wooden bench in a dimly lit room. My usually silky soft hands are now rough, rougher than I would like, but I don't care. I've got paper cuts intricately tracing over my fingers and hands, light lines of momentary pain. My palms and the back of my fingers, especially on my right hand are a dark gray tint. My fingertips on both hands are black, completely pitch black. Covered, my hands are covered with darkness. My hair loosely falls in my face, but I don't dare brush it away, for I know that just one sweep of my hand is all it takes to make my face look like my fingers, covered. My eyes are straining to see details through the lack of good lighting and everytime I look, something looks different. It's frustrating, but I manage control, trying to focus on one thing at a time, not looking back nor forward. Classic rock echoes in the otherwise silent room, but I barely hear it. Instead all that fills my ears is my own breathing and the gentle brushing noise of charcoal on paper. My legs ache for movement, but I remain seating, barely moving at all. I know that if I moved I would not be able to find the exact spot again. If just glancing at the paper and back again changes my view, getting up and moving will alter the entire perspective, so I must be patient. After close to three hours, it is complete. As I sigh in accomplishment, I instantly sit up straighter, stretching my back, as it pops from my poor posture of the past hours. I smile at my drawing, feeling pride in myself, a rare feeling for me. At last I can get up and move, wash my hands, hear the music. It is almost surprising how pale my hands looked after washing away all the black charcoal. Now I notice dark smudges on my jeans and t-shirt, memories of a day, a drawing. I've fallen in love, its amazing to feel skilled, good, proud, to be complimented on something I created. I love drawing with charcoal, no matter how messy it may be.

* Omnibenevolence vs. Omnipotence vs. Existence of Evil - Epicurus

    1. Is God willing to prevent evil, but not able? Then he is not omnipotent.

    2. Is he able, but not willing? Then he is malevolent.

    3. Is he both able and willing? Then whence cometh evil?

    4. Is he neither able nor willing? Then why call him God?



* Perfection vs. Creation - Theodore M. Drange

    1. If God exists, then he is perfect..

    2. If God exists, then he is the creator of the universe.

    3. A perfect being can have no needs or wants.

    4. If any being created the universe, then he must have had some need or want.

    5. Therefore, it is impossible for a perfect being to be the creator of the universe (from 3 and 4).

    6. Hence, it is impossible for God to exist (from 1, 2, and 5).



* God's Jealousy vs. God's Love - Reginald V. Finley, Sr.

    1. "God is love." 1 John 4:8.

    2. "Love is not jealous." 1 Cor 13:4

    3. "I, the Lord thy God, am a jealous God." Exodus 20:5.

    4. The Christian god cannot logically exist.



* Creation of Good vs. Creation of Evil - Reginald V.Finley, Sr.

    1. God is good all of the time.

    2. Everything that God creates is good.

    3. God created evil according to Isaiah 45:7.

    4. Evil is good.



* Omniscience vs. Man's Disbelief and Damnation to Hell - Reginald V. Finley, Sr.

    1. God is all-knowing.

    2. Before I was born God knew I wouldnt believe in him.

    3. I was born to go to Hell.



* God's Plan vs. Free-Will - Reginald V. Finley, Sr.

    1. God has an unchangeable plan for everything past, present & future.

    2. Everything that occurs past, present and future will be part of God's unchanging plan.

    3. Thoughts and actions occur and are part of God's unchanging plan.

    4. Thoughts and actions cannot be anything other than what God has planned.

    5. Free-will doesn't exist.



* Immutability vs. Creation - Theodore M. Drange

    1. If God exists, then he is immutable.

    2. If God exists, then he is the creator of the universe.

    3. An immutable being cannot at one time have an intention and then at a later time not have that intention.

    4. For any being to create anything, prior to the creation he must have had the intention to create it, but at a later time, after the creation, no longer have the intention to create it.

    5. Thus, it is impossible for an immutable being to have created anything (from 3 and 4).

    6. Therefore, it is impossible for God to exist (from 1, 2, and 5)



* Christian God's Desire for Atheism

    1. The Christian God wants all men to know he exists so that they can be saved and go to Heaven.

    2. The Christian God is omnipotent, omniscient, and omnibenevolent.

    3. The Christian God knows what sufficient evidences he can provide to convince all men of his existence.

    4. Not all men are convinced of God's existence.

    5. The Christian God chooses to not provide sufficient evidence to convince all men that he exists.

    6. Therefore, The Christian God wants atheists to exist.

As I was finally starting to clean my room a bit today, I stumbled upon all the old college brochures and information I had saved from the past year. I stared at the RMCAD and Otis ones for a while, my two favorite schools, and sighed, throwing them into the trash with all the rest. I also found my Otis acceptance letter and with tears threatening to spill, also threw it away. I have to get that idea out of my head. No matter how wonderful the fantasy of going off to a fancy art school seems, I know I can't. I'm staying in Vegas, going to CCSN, probably going to find a different major, a new focus on my life and give up on being an artist. I could never do it. I don't have the drive, the talent, the ability to be an artist. All I have is dreams, fantasy. I haven't lifted a pencil and drawn anything since school let out and moving my sketch book from my desk, where it has lived for months, years maybe, into my closet where it belongs was just another symbol to me that its over. I can't live a dream. I have to face the facts. I'm not an artist. I'm horrible at drawing. I can visualize, but I have no way of expressing it and no drive, determination, desire to. All during high school, I was always the one completely sure of what I wanted to do, be a computer animator. Don't get me wrong, I still want to, but all the wanting in the world doesn't change the lack of ability. I've given up and I've never felt more lost. I have no idea what to do with the rest of my life.
